Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Situation2: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Story: I walked through the front door, phone buzzing in my pocket, and saw my younger brother slump onto the couch, eyes red and shoulders hunched. He didn’t say anything, but I could tell something was wrong—he always tried to hide it, but I knew the signs. I wanted to sit next to him, ask what happened, and just be there like I always promised I would. But my phone vibrated again, and I glanced down to see another message from my friend, the words sharp and cold. She’d misunderstood my last text, and now she thought I was mad at her. I knew if I didn’t call her right away, things would only get worse between us. My brother sniffled, wiping his nose on his sleeve, and I felt torn in two. I could hear the expectation in both silences: my brother needing me to listen, my friend needing me to explain. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, phone in hand, caught between the two people who needed me most.
